Pushing Calisthenics Adoption

The start

While talking with two friends -used to go workout together- we spotted an opportunity; there was a market opening up for calisthenics in Mexico. As we saw an increasing interest in people looking for an affordable fitness lifestyle and an alternative to gym workouts, we decided to put together a project that could satisfy those demands.


Role:

My role in the team was to own the projects' online Marketing and Web Development efforts. I took full ownership of creating the structure and narrative of the first social media strategy, focused on brand awareness.

Creating a brand

We started the project from scratch, our main constraint was the lack of budget and brand recognition.
We chose to counter the aforementioned difficulties by taking advantage of two factors.


  • a) We had outstanding talent: A certified calisthenics athlete in the team.

  • b) Fitness Youtube was picking up momentum.

Had been a Youtube user since 2008 (approximately). I was around long enough to note what worked and what didn't work. My interest in fitness during the prior 2 years gave me a grasp of the audience and content creators of the United States. We decided to use those practices as a benchmark.


Site homepage

THE CONTENT STRATEGY WAS BASED ON

  • -Impressive content: High skilled moves.
  • -Educational content: Video tutorials and workouts.
  • -Consistency: Posting calendar.
  • -Narrative: Content that resonated with market needs and had chronological order.
  • -Multiplatform approach: We used our website, Youtube channel, and Facebook to fit our content to different formats and communication styles.

The Outcome: UW Calisthenics Brand

Thousands of people reached through our tutorials. We managed to increase the fanbase following by 175x (from 400 followers).


Launched personal trainig sessions program.


This project proved the importance of putting yourself at the right position in the right time. We increased our chances of success by providing as much value as we possibly could, understanding our projects' strengths, capabilities, and what the market needed.
